The inner thighs scissor toward each other and the tailbone is pointed downward and the chin slightly tucked.  The spine is long and extended.  The lower body stays static and your Eagle arms stay wrapped extending away from the body.  The gaze is forward.
lunge_crescent_eagle_forward.Pose Benefits: Creates flexible strength.  Promotes stability in the front and back of the torso.  Tones the lower body.  Stretches the shoulders, arms, neck, belly, groins (psoas) and the muscles of the back. Strengthens and stretches the thighs, calves and ankles.

lunge_twist_extended_bound.Pose Description: From Revolved Crescent Lunge with Arms Extended, lower the top hand around the back with palm facing out.  Bottom hand wraps underneath the thigh.  Bend the elbow and extend the hand to reach the other hand.  Bind the hands together.  If the hands cannot reach, use a strap.  Heart is open.  The gaze is over the top shoulder.
lunge_twist_extended_bound.Pose Benefits: Deeply stretches the spine, chest, lungs, shoulders and groin.  Stimulates the internal abdominal organs and kidneys.

lunge_crescent_eagle_backbend.Pose Name: Crescent Lunge with Eagle Arm Backbend
lunge_crescent_eagle_backbend.Pose Description: From Crescent Lunge with Eagle Arms, hinge up and back from your hips.  Lift your eagle arm wrapped arms upward and away from your body to take a gentle backbend.  The foot of the front leg is rooted on the earth with the knee directly above and tracking the ankle in a 90-degree angle.  The back leg is straight, no bend in the knee, and the weight is distributed backwards onto the toes.  The inner thighs scissor toward each other and the tailbone is pointed downward, gaze upward.
lunge_crescent_eagle_backbend.Pose Benefits: Creates flexible strength.  Promotes stability in the front and back of the torso.  Tones the lower body.  Stretches the shoulders, arms, neck, belly, groins (psoas) and the muscles of the back.  Strengthens and stretches the thighs, calves and ankles.

lunge_crescent_twist.Pose Description: The front foot of one leg is rooted on the earth with the knee directly above and tracking the ankle in a 90-degree angle.  The back leg is straight, no bend in the knee, and the weight is distributed backwards onto the toes as the back heel pushes back and down toward the earth.  The inner thighs scissor toward each other and the pelvis is tucked under with the ribcage lifted and the chin slightly tucked.  The spine is long and extended.  The heart is open.  The torso twists toward one side and the arm corresponding toward the back leg reaches toward the back.  Both arms are straight.  Wrists and the fingers are extended and spread wide.  Gaze is over the back shoulder.
lunge_crescent_twist.Pose Benefits: Creates flexible strength.  Promotes stability in the front and back of the torso.  Tones the lower body.  Stretches the chest, lungs, shoulders, arms, neck, belly, groins (psoas) and the muscles of the back.  Strengthens and stretches the thighs, calves and ankles.

downward_dog_knee_to_forehead.Pose Name: Downward-Facing Dog with Knee to Forehead
downward_dog_knee_to_forehead.Pose Description: From Downward-Facing Dog, one knee is pulled into the chest or to the forehead depending upon your range of flexibility.  The belly is pulled up and in.  The back is arched in a Cobra position.  The belly is pulled toward the spine and the chin is tucked.  The gaze is down and slightly forward.
downward_dog_knee_to_forehead.Pose Benefits: Calms the brain and helps relieve stress and mild depression.  Energizes the body.  Stretches the shoulders, neck, hamstrings, calves, arches, and hands.  Strengthens the arms and legs.  Helps relieve the symptoms of menopause.  Relieves menstrual discomfort when done with the head supported.  Helps prevent osteoporosis.  Improves digestion.  Relieves headache, insomnia, back pain, and fatigue.  Therapeutic for high blood pressure, asthma, flat feet, sciatica, and sinusitis.  Warms up the ankles and the toes.  Strengthens abdominal muscles.

warrior_iii_airplane.Pose Description: Begin in Mountain with Prayer Hands.  Find a focal point in front of you and begin to shift your weight to one foot.  Root down into your standing leg and lift your opposite leg behind you.  Keep lifting it as you hinge your torso forward to form a giant T.  Extend your arms straight our or keep them close to your side body.  Keep your hips square and the knee of your floating leg facing downward.  Flex your floating foot and engage your grounded leg.
warrior_iii_airplane.Pose Benefits: Strengthens the ankles and legs.  Tones the abdomen.  Improves balance and posture.

warrior_iii_prayer.Pose Description: Begin in Mountain with Prayer Hands.  Find a focal point in front of you and begin to shift your weight to one foot.  Root down into your standing leg and lift your opposite leg behind you.  Keep lifting it as you hinge your torso forward to form a giant T.  Hands stay together at the heart in prayer position.  Keep your hips square and the knee of your floating leg facing downward.  Flex your floating foot and engage your grounded leg.
warrior_iii_prayer.Pose Benefits: Strengthens the ankles and legs.  Tones the abdomen.  Improves balance and posture.

lunge_crescent_hands_on_hips_forward_ben.Pose Name: Crescent Lunge Halfway Fold with Hands on Hips
lunge_crescent_hands_on_hips_forward_ben.Pose Description: From Crescent Lunge with Hands on Hips, hinge forward with a flat back.  The lower body stays static.  The hips are squared towards the front.  The upper torso gently bends forward from the crease of the hip with a straight line from the crown of the head to the back heel.  The gaze is forward and the navel is drawn inward to protect the lower back.
lunge_crescent_hands_on_hips_forward_ben.Pose Benefits: Creates flexible strength.  Promotes stability in the front and back of the torso and strengthens the core.  Tones the lower body.  Strengthens and stretches the thighs, calves and ankles.

lunge_crescent_twist_reverse.Pose Description: The front foot of one leg is rooted on the earth with the knee directly above and tracking the ankle in a 90-degree angle.  The back leg is straight, no bend in the knee, and the weight is distributed backwards onto the toes as the back heel pushes back and down toward the earth.  The inner thighs scissor toward each other and the pelvis is tucked under with the ribcage lifted and the chin slightly tucked.  The spine is long and extended.  The heart is open.  The arm corresponding to the front leg reaches back and down to touch the back thigh.  The other arm extends upwards toward the sky and slightly toward the back.
lunge_crescent_twist_reverse.Pose Benefits: Creates flexible strength.  Promotes stability in the front and back of the torso.  Tones the lower body.  Stretches the chest, lungs, shoulders, arms, neck, belly, groins (psoas) and the muscles of the back.  Strengthens and stretches the thighs, calves and ankles.

lunge_crescent_forward_bend.Pose Description: The foot of the front leg is rooted on the earth with the knee directly above and tracking the ankle in a 90-degree angle.  The back leg is straight, no bend in the knee, and the weight is distributed backwards onto the toes as the back heel pushes back and down toward the earth.  The inner thighs scissor toward each other and the pelvis is tucked under with the ribcage lifted and the chin slightly tucked.  The spine is long and extended.  The lower body stays static.  The upper torso gently bends forward from the crease of the hip with a straight line.  The gaze is forward.
lunge_crescent_forward_bend.Pose Benefits: Creates flexible strength.  Promotes stability in the front and back of the torso.  Tones the lower body.  Stretches the chest, lungs, shoulders, arms, neck, belly, groins (psoas) and the muscles of the back.  Strengthens and stretches the thighs, calves and ankles.

lunge_crescent_forward_arms_side.Pose Name: Crescent Lunge Halfway Fold with Airplane Arms
lunge_crescent_forward_arms_side.Pose Description: From Crescent Lunge, hinge your chest forward from your hips and extend your arms back.  Pinky fingers up and thumbs down.  Your wrists and shoulders are in line and your neck is a natural extension of your spine.  Straight line from the crown of your head down to your back heel.  The foot of the front leg is rooted on the earth with the knee directly above and tracking the ankle in a 90-degree angle.  The back leg is straight, no bend in the knee, and the weight is distributed backwards onto the toes.
lunge_crescent_forward_arms_side.Pose Benefits: Creates flexible strength.  Promotes stability in the front and back of the torso.  Tones the lower body.  Stretches the shoulders, arms, neck, belly, groins (psoas) and the muscles of the back.  Strengthens and stretches the thighs, calves and ankles.

lunge_crescent_cactus_arms.Pose Description: From Crescent Lunge, lift your chest upward and back.  Widen your arms into a cactus shape as you expand through your chest.  Elbows are wide and drawing away from the body.  Shoulder blades are pressed together.  Fingers are spread wide.  Eye gaze is upward and the neck is a natural extension of your spine.
lunge_crescent_cactus_arms.Pose Benefits: Stretches the chest, shoulders, arms, neck, belly, groins (psoas) and the muscles of the back.  Strengthens and stretches the thighs, calves and ankles.

lunge_twist_extended.Pose Name: Revolved Crescent Lunge with Arms Extended
lunge_twist_extended.Pose Description: From Revolved Crescent Lunge, slowly release the hands and extend both arms.  Bottom hand can touch the floor or float.  A block may be used for support when needed.  Top hand reaches up toward the sky.  Keep both hands straight and the heart remains open.  Gaze is upward toward the top hand.
lunge_twist_extended.Pose Benefits: Lengthens and stretches the spine.  Creates flexibility in the rib cage.  Stimulates the internal abdominal organs and kidneys.  Opens the shoulders and strengthens the back muscles.

lunge_prayer.Pose Description: The foot of the front leg is rooted into the earth with the knee directly above and tracking the ankle at a 90-degree angle.  The back leg is straight, no bend in the knee, and the weight is distributed backwards onto the toes as the back heel pushes back and down toward the earth.  The inner thighs scissor toward each other and the pelvis is tucked under with the ribcage lifted and the chin slightly tucked under.  The spine is long and extended.  The heart is open.  The hands are in prayer position.
lunge_prayer.Pose Benefits: Creates flexible strength.  Promotes stability in the front and back of the torso.  Tones the lower body.  Stretches the chest, lungs, shoulders, arms, neck, back, abdomen, and groin (psoas muscles).  Strengthens and stretches the thighs, calves and ankles.

lunge_crescent_triceps.Pose Description: Begin in Crescent Lunge and bend your elbows to bring your thumb knuckles to the back of your neck.  Keep the hips squared and lift up through your rib cage with the option to hinge upward and back.
lunge_crescent_triceps.Pose Benefits: Stretches the chest, triceps, and hips.  Strengthens the shoulders, arms and back muscles.  Strengthens the thighs, calves and ankles.

lunge_twist.Pose Description: From Crescent Lunge with Prayer Hands, slowly twist the spine to one side, hooking the elbow outside of the knee.  Stack the shoulders on top of each other, keep the heart open and gaze up toward the sky.  On the inhale, elongate the spine and on the exhale take the twist slightly deeper.
lunge_twist.Pose Benefits: Lengthens and stretches the spine.  Creates flexibility in the rib cage.  Stimulates the internal abdominal organs and kidneys.

pyramid.Pose Description: From a standing position with one leg forward and one back lean the torso forward at the crease of the hip joint.  Stop when the torso is parallel to the floor.  Press the fingertips or flat palms to the floor on either side of the front foot, maintaining a straight elongated spine.  If it isn't possible to touch the floor, or to maintain a straight spine, support the hands on a pair of blocks.  Press the thighs back and lengthen the torso forward, lifting up through the top of the sternum.  Then, as flexibility allows, bring the front torso closer to the top of the thigh without rounding the spine.  Eventually the long front torso will rest down on the thigh.  The gaze is down.
pyramid.Pose Benefits: Calms the brain.  Stretches the spine, the shoulders, the hips and the hamstrings.  Strengthens the legs.  Stimulates the abdominal organs.  Improves posture and sense of balance.  Improves digestion.

seated_forward_bend_preparation.Pose Description: Transitional pose to get into Seated Forward Bend I.From a seated position with the sits bones rooted into the earth the knees are bent.  The thighs connect with the chest.  The peace fingers are wrapped around the big toes.  The ribcage is lifted.  The gaze is forward.

seated_forward_bend_revolved.Pose Description: Begin in a seated position with your legs straight in front.  Hinge forward and catch on to the edge of your left foot with your right hand, palm facing up.  Stay forward and take your left arm over the right allowing your left palm to catch the edge of your right foot. Turn your torso slightly towards your left to bring your right arm to the outer left thigh, lining your arm pit up with your knee.  Adjust the legs so they stay in line and then pull your chest through both arms to work towards your deepest side stretch.  Repeat on the other side.
seated_forward_bend_revolved.Pose Benefits: Stretches the spine, legs, torso and arms.

seated_forward_bend_half_lotus_preparati.Pose Name: Seated Half Bound Lotus Forward Bend (Preparation)
seated_forward_bend_half_lotus_preparati.Pose Description: Transitional pose to get into Seated Half Bound Lotus Forward Bend.

lunge_kneeling_arm_up.Pose Name: Lunge on the Knee with Arm Extended Up
lunge_kneeling_arm_up.Pose Description: From Lunge on the Knee, the arm corresponding to the bent knee extends to the sky as the torso rotates open.  The palm is open out and the fingers are spread wide.  The other arm (which is in the same plane as the top arm) remains on the inside of the thigh with the palm rooted to the earth for balance.  The gaze is up toward the sky, unless it hurts your neck, then take the gaze to the earth.
lunge_kneeling_arm_up.Pose Benefits: Creates flexible strength.  Promotes stability in the front and back of the torso.  Tones the lower body.  Opens the shoulders.

crooked_monkey_forearm.Pose Description: Begin in Lizard on the Knee.  Send your back knee as far back as possible to avoid being directly on the kneecap.  Keep your front knee in line with your front ankle.  Flex your front foot to protect your ankle and allow your thigh to open outward.  Stay grounded in your outside forearm, shoulder over elbow.  Bend your back heel towards your body and reach for your foot with your inside hand.  Pull your heel close towards you for a hamstring stretch.  Push your heel into your hand for a thoracic spine opening and gaze over your top shoulder towards your foot.
crooked_monkey_forearm.Pose Benefits: Stretches the hip flexors, thoracic spine and quadriceps.  Improves flexibility in hip ligaments, back and strengthens muscles in your legs.

lunge_hands_on_mat.Pose Description: The front foot of one leg is rooted onto the earth with the knee directly above and tracking the ankle in a 90-degree angle.  The back leg is straight, no bend in the knee, and the weight is distributed backwards onto the toes as the back heel pushes back and down toward the earth.  The inner thighs scissor toward each other and the pelvis is tucked under with the ribcage lifted and the chin slightly tucked.  Both arms are straight (no bend in the elbows) on the inside of the front knee.  The palms are pressed into the earth with the fingers spread wide and the knuckles flat.  The gaze is forward and down following the natural extension of the neck.
lunge_hands_on_mat.Pose Benefits: Creates flexibility and strength.  Promotes stability in the front and back of the torso.  Tones the lower body.  Stretches the chest, lungs, shoulders, arms, neck, belly, groins (psoas) and the muscles of the back.  Strengthens and stretches the inner thighs, calves and ankles.

lunge_kneeling_hands_on_mat.Pose Name: Lizard on the Knee with Straight Arms
lunge_kneeling_hands_on_mat.Pose Description: From Downward-Facing Dog pose, step your foot between your hands to a lunge position.  The back knee is down.  The arms are straight and positioned on the inside of the front leg.  The palms of the hands are pushing the ground away from the body.  Straight line of energy is maintained throughout the spine.  If a deeper stretch is desired, both forearms may be brought down to the floor and a block may be used for modification.
lunge_kneeling_hands_on_mat.Pose Benefits: Opens hips and hip flexors.  Works the quadriceps and lubricates the joints.  Increases flexibility.

lizard_bound.Pose Description: Begin in Lizard with Straight Arms and tuck your arm under the front leg to bring the thigh as high up as possible towards your shoulder.  Lift your opposite arm up and wrap it behind you to take a bind.  Keep your spine lengthening forward and your back leg activated.  Stay balanced on your back toes and take your eye gaze downward.
lizard_bound.Pose Benefits: Stretches the hips and shoulders.  Improves flexibility in hip ligaments and strengthens muscles in your legs and core.

lizard_kneeling.Pose Description: Begin in Box or Downward-Facing Dog.  Step one foot forward to the outside edge of the same side hand.  Both arms should be on the inside of your front bent knee.  Keep your front knee stacked over your ankle.  Drop to your back knee and extend it back as far as possible.  Distribute your weight evenly among both of your hips and begin to sink your weight downward.  If you feel comfortable, lower down onto both forearms.  Keep your chin lifted and your chest open.
lizard_kneeling.Pose Benefits: Stretches the hip flexors, hamstrings, and quadriceps.  Improves flexibility in hip ligaments and strengthens muscles in your legs.

forward_bend_big_toe_preparation.Pose Description: Transitional pose to get into Big Toe.

camel_preparation.Pose Description: Transitional pose to get into Camel, Little Thunderbolt, or Pigeon.Rise onto your knees and shins, tops of the feet down.  Keep your knees hip width apart.  Shoulders, Hips, and Knees in line.  Bring your hands to your heart and move inward.

camel_easy.Pose Description: Rise onto your knees and shins, tops of your feet down.  Keep your knees hip width apart.  Shoulders, hips, and knees in line.  Bring your hands to your lower back.  Lift your chest upward and back.  Keep pressing your hips forward to keep your hips in line your knees.  Your neck is a natural extension of your spine and your eye gaze is upward.
camel_easy.Pose Benefits: Stretches the entire front of the body, the ankles, thighs, abdomen and chest.  Stretches the deep hip flexors (psoas).  Strengthens back muscles.  Improves posture.

prone_bow_half_preparation.Pose Description: Transitional pose to get into Half Bow.

bow_big_toe_i.Pose Description: Begin in a prone position and come into your Sphinx.  Bend one knee and reach your hand back to catch the edge of the same side foot.  Rotate your elbow out, then up, to allow your knuckles to face backwards and your elbow to point slightly towards the sky.  Once stable, catch the opposite foot with the other hand and do the same thing.  Maintain a firm grip on the toes and lift your chest, thighs, and chin.  Then take your gaze upward.
bow_big_toe_i.Pose Benefits: Opens the chest, shoulders and psoas.  Strengthens the spine.

bow_side.Pose Description: Begin by lying flat on your stomach with your chin resting center and your hands resting at your sides.  Bend your knees.  Reach back with your hands and catch your outer ankles.  As you lift your heels up toward the sky, draw your thighs up, and press your ankles into your hands.  Lift your chest off the ground all at the same time.  Keep your grip and chest expansion as you roll to one side.
bow_side.Pose Benefits: Stretches the entire front of the body, opens the shoulders and chest (pectoral major/minor).  At the same time, strengthens the back muscles.

bow_big_toe_ii.Pose Description: Begin in your Big Toe Bow I.  Maintaining a firm grip on your toes, lower your feet until they touch the sides of your shoulders and breathe.  The elbows can shift forward to deepen the stretch.
bow_big_toe_ii.Pose Benefits: Opens the chest, shoulders, quadriceps and psoas.  Strengthens the spine.

hero_reclining.Pose Description: From a reclined supine position with the lower back pressed to the earth, the knees are bent and the feet are pulled into the side body with arm straight and palms up.  The heads of the thighbones sink deep into the back of the hip sockets.  The knees may lift a little away from the floor to help soften your groins; in fact, you can raise your knees a few inches on a thickly folded blanket.  You can also allow a little bit of space between your knees as long as your thighs remain parallel to each other.  Do not allow the knees to splay wider than your hips as this will cause strain on the hips and lower back.  The gaze is soft and up.
hero_reclining.Pose Benefits: Stretches the abdomen, thighs and deep hip flexors (psoas), knees, and ankles.  Strengthens the arches.  Relieves tired legs.  Improves digestion.  Helps relieves the symptoms of menstrual pain.

hero_twist.Pose Description: Come into Hero.  Sit on a blanket or block if the sit bones don't touch the ground.  Place your left palm behind your left heel and your right palm to the outside of your left knee for a twist.  Sit up straight and initiate the twist from your waist line.  Eye gaze is over your left shoulder.  Repeat on the opposite side.
hero_twist.Pose Benefits: Stretches the thighs, knees, ankles, back muscles and spine.

hero_reclining_extended.Pose Description: Start from Hero pose and slowly transition to Supine Hero pose.  Bring the hands back and straighten the arms with palms facing up.  Roll a blanket underneath the back if needed.
hero_reclining_extended.Pose Benefits: Stretches the abdomen, shoulders, arms and thighs including hip flexors.  Strengthens the back muscles, ankles and knees.  Stimulates the abdominal organs, kidneys, lungs and rib cage.

hero_half_reclining.Pose Description: Begin in Half Hero with your hands by your side body.  Lower back and drop down to your forearms and then all the way down onto your back.  Keep the hips squared up towards the sky.  If the hips are uneven, you can place a blanket under the hip of your straight leg.  Avoid letting the knees come wider than the hips.  Close your eyes, breathe and rest.  Repeat on the other side.
hero_half_reclining.Pose Benefits: Stretches the thighs, knees and ankles.  Strengthens the back muscles.

hero_half.Pose Description: Begin in a seated position.  Lean to one side, bend your opposite knee outward.  Roll your calf out of the way to create space, and place your leg in Hero pose with your heel close to your hip and knees touching.  Distribute your weight evenly among both sit bones and sit up tall.
hero_half.Pose Benefits: Stretches the thighs, knees and ankles.

lunge_hands_on_mat_back.Pose Name: Pyramid with Hands on the Inside of the Leg
lunge_hands_on_mat_back.Pose Description: From a standing position the front and back legs extend away from each other and the inner thighs scissor toward each other.  The spine is long and extended as the upper torso folds over the front leg and the palms reach for the earth on the inside of the leg.  The pelvis is tucked under, the ribcage is lifted and the chin is slightly tucked.  The neck is a natural is extension of the spine and the gaze is down.
lunge_hands_on_mat_back.Pose Benefits: Calms the brain.  Stretches the spine, hips, and hamstrings.  Strengthens the legs.  Stimulates the abdominal organs.  Improves posture and sense of balance.  Improves digestion.

pyramid_preparation.Pose Description: Transitional pose to get into Pyramid.Begin standing and step one foot back.  Front toes stay facing forward.  Back toes can face forward or slightly out to the side.  Square your hips by drawing your back hip forward and your front hip back.  Lift your chest and take reverse prayer or catch opposite elbows behind your back.  Actively lift through the crown of your head or option to lift your chin and take a gentle standing backbend.

dolphin_leg_up.Pose Description: From Downward-Facing Dog, the forearms are planted onto the earth with the elbows narrow and the palms flat in a Sphinx position.  The pelvis is tucked.  The ribcage lifted.  One leg is straight and rooted to the earth, while the other reaches straight toward the sky.  The gaze is down and slightly forward.
dolphin_leg_up.Pose Benefits: Calms the brain and helps relieve stress and mild depression.  Energizes the body.  Stretches the shoulders, hamstrings, calves, arches, and hands.  Strengthens the arms and legs.  Helps relieve the symptoms of menopause.  Relieves menstrual discomfort when done with the head supported.  Helps prevent osteoporosis.  Improves digestion.  Relieves headache, insomnia, back pain, and fatigue.  Therapeutic for high blood pressure, asthma, flat feet, sciatica, and sinusitis.  Warms up the ankles and the toes.

side_lunge_extended.Pose Description: Begin in Side Lunge.  Keep pressing the heel of your straight leg forward to sink deeper into your hips.  Drop your bottom arm down alongside the foot of your bent knee and expand your opposite arm into the sky.  Expand your chest and gaze up.
side_lunge_extended.Pose Benefits: Opens and stretches the hips and legs.  Strengthens the spine and knee joints.

standing_marichi.Pose Description: Begin standing in Mountain.  Shift your weight to one foot, and ground down firmly.  Bend your opposite knee up toward your chest and begin to hug it into the outside of your rib cage.  Hinge from your hip slightly and wrap your arm (same side as bent knee) around your shin.  Wrap your opposite arm behind your lower back and catch opposite fingers or your wrist.  As you pull your shin closer to your body, begin to straighten your spine and keep your grounded leg engaged.  Keep your gaze focused on one spot.  You can also try to enter into this pose from Side Lunge or Garland.
standing_marichi.Pose Benefits: Stretches the shoulders.  Strengthens the legs, ankles and abdominals.  Improves balance and focus.

side_lunge_extended_bound.Pose Description: Begin in Side Lunge with Arms Extended.  Keep pressing the heel of your straight leg forward to sink deeper into your hips.  Wrap your bottom arm in front of your shin and bring your extended arm up and around to reach for your bind.  Catch opposite hands.  Expand your chest and gaze up.
side_lunge_extended_bound.Pose Benefits: Opens and stretches the hips, legs, shoulders and arms.  Strengthens the spine and knee joints.

seated_cat.Pose Description: From Easy, take your cat spine.  Root into your sit bones, pull your navel inward toward your spine and chin to chest.  Gaze is towards your navel.  Rest your palms softly on your knees.
seated_cat.Pose Benefits: Warms up and elongates the spine.

mountain.Pose Description: From Mountain pose, the hands come together at the heart in prayer position.  The gaze is forward.
mountain.Pose Benefits: Improves posture.  Strengthens thighs, knees, and ankles.  Firms abdomen and buttocks.  Relieves sciatica.  Reduces flat feet.

lord_of_the_dance_revolved.Pose Description: From standing, shift the weight to one foot, bend your opposite knee and bring the heel behind you towards your glute, reach your opposite hand back to catch the foot or ankle of your bent knee.  Hinge forward from your hip and at the same time arch your back and press your foot or ankle into the sole of your hand.  Gaze is forward and upward and the balancing arm can be extended for better balance.
lord_of_the_dance_revolved.Pose Benefits: Stretches the shoulders, the chest, the thighs, the groins and abdomen.  Strengthens the legs and the ankles.  Improves balance.

lord_of_the_dance_preparation.Pose Description: Transitional pose to get into Standing Bow or Lord of the Dance.

lord_of_the_dance_full.Pose Description: From Mountain flex one knee and draw the foot up toward the hip.  Then clasp the foot with the hand on the same side of the body by rotating the elbow in and up while extending the leg back and up from the hip.  Lift the opposite arm overhead, bend the elbow and grasp the foot.  Gaze is up.  Maintain Bandhas throughout the pose for stabilization.  Remember to keep the standing leg straight and strong while remaining aware of the tendency to lock the standing leg knee.  Keep the pelvis level to create symmetrical foundation for the full extension of the spine.  Press the tailbone back and down, expand the chest, press the lower tips of the shoulder blades forward and up to facilitate opening of the heart center.  If stable and at ease, release the crown of the head toward the arch of the foot and draw the elbows together.  Breathe!
lord_of_the_dance_full.Pose Benefits: Stretches the shoulders, the chest, the thighs, the groins, and the abdomen.  Strengthens the legs and the ankles.  Improves balance.

supine_foot_behind_head.Pose Description: Begin Foot Behind the Head I.  Extend your chin to keep the leg secure behind the head and recline backwards onto the ground.  Keep the extended leg energized and straight.
supine_foot_behind_head.Pose Benefits: Stretches the spine, hips and hamstrings.

headstand_tripod_knees_on_elbows.Pose Name: Tripod Headstand with Knees on Elbows
headstand_tripod_knees_on_elbows.Pose Description: The body is inverted and perpendicular to the earth with the knees resting on the elbows.  The weight of the body is balanced between the crown of the head and the elbows that are bent in a 90-degree angle.  The palms are flat and the fingers point forward.  The head and hands are spaced equally forming an equilateral triangle.  The neck is a natural extension of the spine.  The chin is tucked slightly in toward the sternum.  The gaze is straight.
headstand_tripod_knees_on_elbows.Pose Benefits: Calms the brain and helps relieve stress and mild depression.  Stimulates the pituitary and pineal glands.  Strengthens the arms, legs, and spine.  Strengthens the lungs.  Tones the abdominal organs.  Improves digestion.  Helps relieve the symptoms of menopause.  Therapeutic for asthma, infertility, insomnia, and sinusitis.

box_hand_to_ankle.Pose Description: From Box, one arm extends under the body and stretches out in a perpendicular direction.  The opposite arm reaches straight forward while the forehead rest softly on the earth in the direction of the extended arm.  The gaze is to the side.
box_hand_to_ankle.Pose Benefits: Gently stretches the hips, thighs, and ankles.  Calms the brain and helps relieve stress and fatigue.  Relieves back and neck pain when done with head and torso supported.  Stretches the shoulders.

toe_squat.Pose Description: Begin in Box.  Curl your toes under and take a seat onto your heels.  Try to resist the urge to lift up off your heels.  Keep your knees grounded.  To intensify the pose, begin to lean back slightly.  Hands can rest on your thighs or take prayer palms to your heart.  Close your eyes and breathe into any uncomfortableness.
toe_squat.Pose Benefits: Stretches the toes and ankles.  Strengthens the knee joints.

seated_forward_bend_wide_angle_preparati.Pose Name: Seated Wide Legged Forward Bend I (Preparation)
seated_forward_bend_wide_angle_preparati.Pose Description: Transitional pose to get into Seated Wide Legged Forward Bend I

child_wide.Pose Description: From Child's, the knees are open wide and the big toes are touching with most of the weight of the body on the heels of the feet.  The forehead rests softly onto the earth.  The arms extend to the front with the fingers spread wide.  The gaze is down and inward.
child_wide.Pose Benefits: Gently stretches the hips, thighs, and ankles.  Calms the brain and helps relieve stress and fatigue.  Relieves back and neck pain when done with head and torso supported.

table_knee_to_forehead.Pose Description: From Box, one knee is pulled into the chest or to the forehead as flexibility allows.  The belly is pulled up and in.  The back is arched in a Cobra position with the chin tucked.  The gaze is toward the back.
table_knee_to_forehead.Pose Benefits: Calms the brain and helps relieve stress and mild depression.  Energizes the body.  Stretches the shoulders, neck, hamstrings, calves, arches, and hands.  Strengthens the arms and legs.  Helps relieve the symptoms of menopause.  Relieves menstrual discomfort when done with the head supported.  Helps prevent osteoporosis.  Improves digestion.  Relieves headache, insomnia, back pain, and fatigue.  Therapeutic for high blood pressure, asthma, flat feet, sciatica, and sinusitis.  Warms up the ankles and the toes.  Strengthens abdominal muscles.

cat_balance_elbow_to_knee.Pose Description: From Balancing Table, pull your knee and elbow in towards your chest to make contact.  Hollow out your belly into a cat spine to activate your core and tuck your chin towards your chest.  Keep your supported palm rooted and your shoulder over your wrist.

cat_balance.Pose Description: From Box, extend one foot toward the back, knee is straight, hips squared to the floor.  Slowly extend the opposite arm forward, keep the hand and neck in line with the spine.
cat_balance.Pose Benefits: Stretches the extended leg and arm.  Strengthens the hips and shoulders.  Improves flexibility and balance.

headstand_tripod_preparation.Pose Description: Transitional pose to get into Tripod Headstand.From a standing position, the body is folded forward from a wide stance.  The elbows are bent in a 90-degree angle and the fingers are in line with the toes.  The palms are flat and the knuckles are evenly pressed into the earth.  The crown of the head is resting on the earth slightly in front of the hands forming an equilateral triangle.  The neck is a natural extension of the spine.  The chin is slightly tucked in toward the sternum.
headstand_tripod_preparation.Category: Arm Balance And Inversion / Forward Bend

headstand_supported_preparation.Pose Description: Transitional pose to get into Supported Headstand.In this inverted posture the body's weight is balanced between the crown of the head, interlaced fingers (pinky fingers spoon), forearms and the knees.  The interlaced fingers are wrapped around the head with the forearms narrowed to secure the head and protect the neck.  At the same time the back ribs are pushed back to widen the back body as the shoulder blades move away from the ears and pull together securing a safe and strong starting position for Supported Headstand.  The gaze is naturally toward the knees.

bow_half.Pose Description: From Box, extend one arm forward and the opposite leg toward the back, keep the neck in line with the spine.  Bend the top knee and bring the extended hand backwards to catch the foot or toes.  Start to lift the knee and chest higher to create an arch like a bow.
bow_half.Pose Benefits: Stretches the back muscles and the front body.  Stimulates the abdominal organs and lungs.  Improves balance.

table_leg_up.Pose Description: From Box, one knee is resting squared to the earth.  The other leg is extended and reaches up toward the sky.  The gaze is down.
table_leg_up.Pose Benefits: Tones and strengthens the standing leg.  Improves flexibility.  Opens the hips.

box_twist.Pose Description: From Box, root down into one hand and reach the opposite arm straight into the sky.  Extend your rib cage upwards and try to stack your top shoulder in line over your bottom shoulder.  Take the gaze toward the top hand.
box_twist.Pose Benefits: Helps with grounding, balance, and spinal extension.

headstand_supported_preparation_hips_ove.Pose Name: Supported Headstand with Toes on the Ground
headstand_supported_preparation_hips_ove.Pose Description: Transitional pose to get into Supported Headstand.From your Box, drop to your forearms and interlace your fingers (pinky fingers spoon).  Drop the crown of your head between your forearms allowing your interlaced fingers to cradle your head.  Keep your forearms narrow to create a strong base and to protect your neck.  Curl your toes under and straighten your legs.  Begin walking your feet closer to your head until your hips are stacked over your shoulders.  Engage your abdominals and keep pressing your forearms into the ground so there is little weight on the crown of your head.
headstand_supported_preparation_hips_ove.Category: Arm Balance And Inversion / Forward Bend

goddess_one_heel_raise.Pose Description: From Goddess, lift one heel up while keeping the other rooted.  Keep your heart lifted and core engaged.  Continue outer rotating your thighs back, tailbone down.  Lift your heel as high as possible.  Repeat on the other side.
goddess_one_heel_raise.Pose Benefits: Strengthens the glutes, hips, thighs, and calves.

goddess_cactus_arms.Pose Description: From Goddess, bend your elbows out wide to create a 90-degree angle with your arms.  Wrists and elbows in line and elbows and shoulders in line.  Palms open and fingers spread wide.  Actively engage your shoulders and release them down and away from your ears.  Keep your heart lifted and continue outer rotating your thighs back, tailbone down, toes out, heels in.
goddess_cactus_arms.Pose Benefits: Strengthens the glutes, hips, thighs, calves, ankles, shoulders and arms.

goddess_both_heels_raise.Pose Description: From Goddess, lift one heel up and then the other to balance on the toe mounds of your feet.  Keep your heart lifted and core engaged.  Continue outer rotating your thighs back, tailbone down.  Lift your heels as high as possible.
goddess_both_heels_raise.Pose Benefits: Strengthens the glutes, hips, thighs, and calves.

goddess_arms_up.Pose Description: From Goddess, extend your arms up, wrists over shoulders.  Actively engage your shoulders and release them down and away from your ears.  Keep your heart lifted and energize your fingers.  Continue outer rotating your thighs back, tailbone down, toes out, heels in.
goddess_arms_up.Pose Benefits: Strengthens the glutes, hips, thighs, calves, ankles, shoulders and arms.

knee_pile_twist.Pose Description: From Shoelace, place one hand on your top knee as leverage.  Ground your opposite hand behind your hip.  Lengthen your spine, press into your hands and twist.  Take your eye gaze past your shoulder.
knee_pile_twist.Pose Benefits: Stretches and strengthens the side rig cage, spine and massages the stomach and kidneys.  Improves flexibility in the knees, hips and spine.

knee_pile_forward.Pose Description: From Shoelace, walk your hands forward and hinge from your hips.  Keep your sit bones rooted to the ground and relax your ankles.  Allow your neck to release.
knee_pile_forward.Pose Benefits: Stretches the ankles, glutes, hips and thighs.

knee_pile_eagle.Pose Description: Begin in Shoelace.  Take your eagle arm bind by placing one elbow on top of the other.  The knee that is on top should correspond with the elbow on the bottom.  Lift your elbows in line with your shoulders and draw your forearms away from your face.  If possible, keep wrapping your arms until your palms meet; otherwise press the back of your hands towards each other.  Keep your sit bones rooted and lengthen your spine.
knee_pile_eagle.Pose Benefits: Strengthens and stretches the shoulders, arms, hips and knees.

knee_pile_eagle_forward.Pose Name: Shoelace Forward Bend with Eagle Arms
knee_pile_eagle_forward.Pose Description: Begin in Shoelace with Eagle Arms.  Hinge forward and allow your elbows to rest on the knees.  If you can keep your sit bones rooted, rest you elbows or arms out on the ground in front of your knees.
knee_pile_eagle_forward.Pose Benefits: Strengthens and stretches the shoulders, arms, hips and knees.

table.Pose Description: From a seated position place the hands on the floor about one foot behind the hips with the fingertips pointed forward toward hips.  Keep knees bent and feet close to hips while pressing through the hands and feet to lift the hips creating an inverted U with the body into Table.  Relax the head back and gaze at the tip of your nose.
table.Pose Benefits: Strengthens the arms, the wrists, and the legs.  Stretches the shoulders, the chest, and the front ankles.

plank_upward_leg_up.Pose Description: Begin in Upward Plank and lift one leg into the sky, energizing through the toes.  Make it your intention to keep the opposite big toe rooted to the ground and lift the hips higher.  Bring awareness to the shoulders and keep them in line with the wrists.  Relax the crown of your head back if the neck allows.
plank_upward_leg_up.Pose Benefits: Strengthens the core, arms, the wrists, and the legs. Stretches the shoulders, the chest, and the front ankles.

plank_upward_preparation.Pose Description: Transitional pose to get into Upward Plank.

seated_cow.Pose Description: From Easy, take a gentle backbend and arch your back.  Root into your sit bones, lift your chest upward toward the sky and take your gaze up.  Rest your palms softly on your knees.
seated_cow.Pose Benefits: Warms up and elongates the spine.

bow_preparation.Pose Description: Transitional pose to get into Bow or Frog.From a prone position with the abdomen on the earth and the knees bent (and no wider than the hips) the hands grip the ankles (but not the tops of the feet) in preparation for Bow pose.  The gaze is down or forward.

chair_twist_extended.Pose Description: From Revolved Chair, one arm reaches up to the sky and the other reaches down to the earth on the inside or the outside of the knee, depending upon your flexibility.  Keep the shoulder blades squeezed together and the fingers extended out.  The ribcage is lifted and the heart is open.  The gaze is toward the sky, unless it hurts your neck, then the gaze is toward the earth.
chair_twist_extended.Pose Benefits: Increases the flexibility of the spine and back and stretches the shoulders.  Strengthens the legs.  Increases flexibility of the hip and knee joints.  Improves balance.  Opens the groin and stretches the hamstrings.

elephant_trunk_preparation.Pose Description: Begin in Rock the Baby by bringing the knee and foot into the creases of your elbows.  Release your foot, keep it lifted and send it forward.  At the same time, thread the arm that is closest to your knee thru to create a trunk with the leg as high up on your shoulder as possible.  Ground your palms evenly in line with your shoulders and sit up straight.  Energize through your straight leg.
elephant_trunk_preparation.Pose Benefits: Stretches the hips.  Strengthens the entire core, arms and legs.

seated_visvamitra.Pose Description: Begin in Seated Hip Opener, threading your arm through to create a stable trunk as high up on your arm as possible.  Using the opposite hand, catch the outside edge of your foot.  Straighten your leg, press your chest through using the leverage of your grounded arm and palm to press your thigh back and the ground away.  Flex the foot of your grounded leg to stay active.  Equally distribute the weight as much as possible between the hips.  Keep pulling your top hand back into the lifted foot through the arm bone, wrapping your top shoulder blade into the back ribs.
seated_visvamitra.Pose Benefits: Stretches hamstrings, hips, side body and shoulders.

figure_four.Pose Description: Begin in Mountain with Prayer Hands and lift one leg to a table top position while keeping your opposite foot rooted on the earth.  Outer rotate the knee of your floating leg and place your ankle on top of the opposite thigh, above your knee.  You can use your hands to slide your shin closer up.  Begin to shift your weight back as if you are sitting in a chair and send some weight to the heel of your grounding foot.  Flex the foot of your crossed ankle and keep outer rotating your knee as you hinge your hips back deeper.  Keep your chest lifted.  Hands can come to your heart and find a focal point to gaze at.
figure_four.Pose Benefits: Strengthen quadriceps, the ankle and foot muscles.  Encourages core stability.  Stretches the outer hip and glute muscles and improves balance and concentration.

fire_log_forward.Pose Description: From your Fire Log, keep a flat back and begin to hinge forward into the stretch.  Walk your hands as far out as possible while keeping your sit bones rooted.
fire_log_forward.Pose Benefits: Opens the hips & glutes.  Strengthens the back muscles by elongating the spine.  Improves alignment of the spine; thereby improving posture.

staff_inverted_leg_up.Pose Description: Begin in Inverted Staff.  Walk your feet in slightly to feel stable.  Press firmly into your forearms and lift one leg into the sky.  Send energy to your top leg.
staff_inverted_leg_up.Pose Benefits: Stretches the entire front body and opens the chest.  Strengthens core and balance.

staff_inverted_preparation.Pose Description: Transitional pose to get into Inverted Staff.

gorilla_preparation.Pose Description: Transitional pose to get into Gorilla.

boat_half.Pose Description: From a seated position the hands are gripped around the back of the legs and the knees are bent in a 90-degree angle.  Both legs are pulled in toward the abdomen.  The core is engaged to maintain balance on the sits bones (be sure that the back does not round).  The front of the torso lengthens between the pubis and top of the sternum as the spine extends in both directions reaching up to the sky and rooting down to the earth.  The gaze is forward and Bandhas are engaged.
boat_half.Pose Benefits: Strengthens the abdomen, hip flexors and spine.  Stimulates the kidneys, thyroid, prostate glands and intestines.  Helps relieve stress.  Improves digestion.

boat_bind.Pose Description: Begin seated with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor, hands resting by your hips.  Keeping your spine straight, lean back slightly and lift your feet to table top, then straighten your legs.  Draw in your low back, lift your chest, and lengthen the front of your torso as you walk your index and middle (peace) fingers to your big toes.
boat_bind.Pose Benefits: Improves balance and digestion.  Stretches your hamstrings, abdominals, spine and hip flexors.

boat_low.Pose Description: From a seated position or Boat pose, lower yourself down to a hover.  Avoid letting your legs or upper back touch the ground.  Keep your belly drawn in.  Both legs are extended and the toes are activated.  The core is engaged to maintain balance on the sit bones.
boat_low.Pose Benefits: Strengthens the abdomen, hamstrings, hip flexors and spine.

boat_bind_outside_edge.Pose Description: Begin seated with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor, hands resting by your hips.  Keeping your spine straight, lean back slightly and lift your feet to table top, then straighten your legs.  Draw in your low back, lift your chest, and lengthen the front of your torso.  Walk your hands behind your feet or ankles.  Continue straightening your legs as you pull them closer to your torso.
boat_bind_outside_edge.Pose Benefits: Improves balance and digestion.  Deep stretch for your hamstrings, strengthens abdominals, spine and hip flexors.

seated_on_heels_hands_on_mat_opened_knee.Pose Description: Transitional pose to get into Crow or Crane.The weight of the body is seated on the heels with the knees open, the arms extended straight and the palms of the hands are rooted into the earth between the thighs.  The belly is pulled up and in toward the spine with the ribcage and chin lifted.  The gaze is forward and slightly down.

crane_one_legged.Pose Description: Begin in Crow or Crane and place one inner thigh to the outside of the same side upper arm.  Extend the leg forward and continue to hug the opposite heel up and in.  Press the earth away and straighten both arms as much as possible.Alternatevely begin in Lizard with Straight Arms and tuck your arm under the front leg bringing the thigh as high up as possible towards your shoulder.  Hop your back foot in and place your knee on the back of your opposite triceps as if you were coming into Crow.  Drop your hips and take your eye gaze forward.  Straighten your front leg, shift forward into your palms and hug your back heel up and in.  Squeeze your legs into your arms to stay engaged.The eye gaze is down and slightly forward.
crane_one_legged.Pose Benefits: Strengthens forearms, wrists, shoulders, upper back and abdominal muscles.

crow_side.Pose Description: Start from Side Crow (Preparation) and lean forward.  Bend the elbows, placing the hips and knees on top of the arms.  Lift the chin up and look forward.  Shift more weight onto the arms and tip over, take one foot and then the other off the floor.
crow_side.Pose Benefits: Strengthens arms and wrists.  Improves balance.  Tones the abdominal muscles.

garland.Pose Description: From a squatting position the feet are as close together as possible (keep your heels on the floor if you can; otherwise, support them on a folded mat).  The thighs are slightly wider than the torso.  The torso is leaning gently forward and tucked snugly between the thighs.  The elbows are pressed against the inner knees and the palms are together in Anjali Mudra (Salutation Seal).  The knees resist the elbows to help lengthen the front torso.  The gaze is soft and forward.
garland.Pose Benefits: Stretches the ankles, groins and back torso.  Tones the belly.

standing_forward_bend_half_lotus_prepara.Pose Name: Standing Half Bound Lotus Forward Bend (Preparation)
standing_forward_bend_half_lotus_prepara.Pose Description: Transitional pose to get into Standing Half Bound Lotus Forward Bend.

standing_half_lotus_bound.Pose Description: Transitional pose to get into Standing Half Bound Lotus Forward Bend.Begin in Standing Half Lotus.  Lengthen your spine and reach your arm (bent knee side) to the sky, then reach it behind your back.  Take hold of your opposite elbow, or clasp your toes with your hand.  Keep your grounded leg engaged.  Keep your gaze focused on one spot.

chair_twist_bind.Pose Description: From Revolved Chair, the lower arm weaves in between the legs as the upper arm wraps around the back and the fingers interlace.  The ribcage is lifted.  The gaze toward the sky, unless it hurts your neck, then the gaze toward the earth.
chair_twist_bind.Pose Benefits: Increases the flexibility of the spine and back and stretches the shoulders.  Stretches the lower back.  Challenges the balance.  Powerful detoxification of toxic food, drink, and thoughts.

half_moon_bound_hands.Pose Description: Begin in a full bind around your grounded leg similar to Bound Side Angle.  Keep your bind and shorten your stance by bringing your back leg closer to your grounded leg.  Gaze down to shift all the weight to your grounded leg and begin to lift your back leg up.  Once balanced, keep your hips open to the side, stack your top hip over your bottom hip as you would in Half Moon pose and flex your floating foot.  Send your gaze up if you're feeling stable.

lunge_arm_up.Pose Description: From Lunge, extend the arm (on the side of the body that correlates to the bent knee) to the sky with fingers spread wide.  The other arm remains on the inside or the outside of the thigh (depending upon your flexibility).  The bottom palm is rooted to the earth for support.  Gaze is toward the sky or toward the earth if your neck is sensitive.
lunge_arm_up.Pose Benefits: Creates flexible strength.  Promotes stability in the front and back of the torso.  Tones the lower body.  Opens the shoulders.

half_moon_revolved_bow.Pose Description: From Revolved Half Moon, keep your hips square and bend your top knee.  Reach your top hand for your foot or ankle.  Press your foot or ankle into your hand and draw your heel away from your body.
half_moon_revolved_bow.Pose Benefits: Strengthens the abdomen, ankles, thighs, buttocks and spine.  Stretches the groins, hamstrings, calves, shoulders, chest and spine.  Improves coordination and sense of balance.

half_moon_bound.Pose Description: From a standing position one leg is straight while the other is extended back parallel to the earth (or a little above parallel) and one hand is on the earth (beyond the little-toe side of the foot, about 12 inches) while the other hand reaches back to grasp the outside of the foot or ankle of the raised leg.  The shoulder blades are squeezed together.  The weight of the body is supported mostly by the standing leg while the bottom hand has very little weight on it but is used perceptively to maintain balance.  The upper torso is rotated open to the sky.  Both hips are externally rotated.  Energy is extended actively through the flexed toes to keep the raised leg strong.  The inner ankle of the standing foot is lifted strongly upward, as if drawing energy from the earth.  The sacrum and scapulae are firmly pressed against the back torso and lengthen the coccyx toward the raised leg.  The gaze is either up or down, depending on the condition of the neck.  If the neck is injured, the gaze is down.
half_moon_bound.Pose Benefits: Strengthens the abdomen, ankles, thighs, buttocks and spine.  Stretches the groins, hamstrings, calves, shoulders, chest and spine.  Improves coordination and sense of balance.  Helps relieve stress.  Improves digestion.  Increases circulation.

half_moon_revolved_bound.Pose Description: Begin in a full bind around your grounded leg similar to Bound Revolved Crescent Lunge.  Keep your bind and shorten your stance by bringing your back leg closer to your grounded leg.  Gaze down to shift all the weight to your grounded leg and begin to lift your back leg up.  Once balanced, activate your floating leg and toes like you would in Revolved Half Moon pose.  Send your gaze up if you're feeling stable and try to straighten your grounded leg.
half_moon_revolved_bound.Pose Benefits: Increases flexibility in the spine and back and stretches the shoulders.  Strengthens the legs.  Increases flexibility of the hip and knee joints.  Improves balance.

awkward.Pose Description: From a standing position the heels come up and the arms are extended forward and parallel to the earth.  The fingers are together and the palms are facing down.  The knees are bent.  The pelvis is contracted under, the rib cage is lifted up and the chin is gently tucked toward the sternum.  Bandhas are engaged.  The gaze is to the front.
awkward.Pose Benefits: Improves overall body strength.  Opens pelvis.  Strengthens and tones the leg muscles.  Relieves menstrual cramping.  Reduces fat pocket under the buttocks.  Aligns the skeletal system.  Good for arthritis conditions.  Improves digestion.  Relieves joint pain.  Relieves sciatica.  Improves flexibility in the toes and the ankles.  Exercises the liver, the intestines and the pancreas.

mountain_side_twist.Pose Description: From Mountain, one arm reaches back and the other reaches forward.  The ribcage is lifted and the heart is open.  The hips and knees stay squared to the front and the twist comes from the midsection.  The gaze is toward the back hand, unless it hurts your neck, then the gaze can be forward.
mountain_side_twist.Pose Benefits: Increases the flexibility of the spine and back.  Improves balance.

standing_head_to_knee.Pose Description: From a standing position with the feet together, the weight of the body is shifted to balance on one leg.  The opposite foot is then clasped with both hands and lifted up by pulling the knee in toward the chest.  Fingers are interlaced under the sole of the foot, specifically at the arch.  Avoid placing the thumbs on the tops of the feet.  The standing leg is straight, but the knee joint is not locked.  The standing foot is rooted firmly into the earth while the weight is shifted slightly forward, closer to the ball of the foot, not the heel.  The bent knee then extends straight until it is parallel with the earth.  Maintain balance in the pose with good pranayama (breath work) and Bandhas.  Keep a leveled pelvis.  It is helpful to think about extending the foot up rather than out.  Continue to lengthen the spine from the neck down to the tailbone.  Allow the shoulders to fall into their natural position away from the ears and extend the arms, maintaining the grip on the foot and straightening the leg.  Engage the muscles of the thigh for more stability.  To achieve the full extension of the pose, round the spine and drop the elbows while lowering the head to your knee.  Avoid dropping the abdominals onto your thigh.  Pull the navel up and into the spine while folding forward.  Lower the head to the knee and tuck the chin into the chest into Jalandhara bandha.  This will extend the stretch of the spine up through the neck.  The gaze is toward the knee or out in front.
standing_head_to_knee.Pose Benefits: Improves balance.  Enhances agility.  Helps digestion.  Massages the internal organs.  Improves circulation.  Enhances memory.

mountain_feet_apart.Pose Description: Transitional pose to get into Big Toe, Gorilla, or Rag Doll.Come to standing with your feet hip width apart and place your hands on your hips.

standing_half_lotus.Pose Description: Begin standing in Mountain.  Shift your weight to one foot, and ground down firmly.  Bend your opposite knee up toward your chest to raise your foot and gently bring your heel to rest as high as possible on the front of your grounded thigh or hip.  The sole of your foot should be facing the sky, and the top of your foot should rest on your leg or hip.  Allow your bent knee to drop down.  Eventually, your bent knee will be in line with the knee of your standing leg.  Draw both hips forward and lengthen your spine.  Keep your gaze focused on one spot.  Bring your hands to center in prayer if possible or keep one hand holding your foot and the other at half prayer.
standing_half_lotus.Pose Benefits: Improves posture and balance.  Increases flexibility in hip joints, knees, and ankles.  Strengthens the abdominal muscles.

standing_head_to_knee_preparation.Pose Description: Transitional pose to get into Standing Head to Knee.From a standing position the weight is balanced on one leg while the other leg is bent at the knee and pulled in close to the torso.  The palms meet under the sole of the foot and the fingers are interlaced under the foot (including the thumb).  The spine is straight and the gaze is forward.

tree.Pose Description: From a standing position, one foot is rooted into the earth with the opposite heel rooted into the inner thigh with the toes pointing toward the earth.  The pelvis and the chin are tucked in.  The arms are lifted above the head with the palms together in prayer position.  The gaze is forward.
tree.Pose Benefits: Strengthens the legs, ankles, and feet.  Improves flexibility in the hips and knees.  Improves balance.

chair_prayer.Pose Description: From Chair, the hands come together at the heart in prayer position.  The gaze is forward.
chair_prayer.Pose Benefits: Strengthens the ankles, thighs, calves, and spine.  Stimulates the abdominal organs, diaphragm, and the heart.  Reduces flat feet.

mountain_cactus_arms.Pose Description: From Mountain, extend your chest upward and back for a gentle backbend.  Bend your elbows out wide to create a 90 degree angle with your arms.  Wrists and elbows in line and elbows and shoulders in line.  Palms open and fingers spread wide.  The tailbone is pointed downward.  The ribcage is lifted.  The gaze is toward the sky.
mountain_cactus_arms.Pose Benefits: Elongates the spine.  Brings awareness to your entire body.  Improves posture.  Stretches the pectoral muscles.  Strengthens thighs, knees, and ankles. Firms abdomen and buttocks.

mountain_backbend.Pose Description: From Mountain, stay strong and grounded in your feet.  Bring your hands to your lower back.  Lift your chest upward and back.  Keep pressing your hips forward to keep your hips in line your knees and ankles.  Your neck is a natural extension of your spine and your eye gaze is upward.
mountain_backbend.Pose Benefits: Stretches the entire front of the body, the ankles, thighs, abdomen and chest.  Strengthens back muscles.  Improves posture.

seated_forward_bend_three_limbs_preparat.Pose Description: Transitional pose to get into Seated Three Limbed Forward Bend.

handstand_eagle.Pose Description: From Handstand, come into your Eagle legs.  Wrap one thigh behind the other.  If you can, take the double wrap by hooking your toes behind your opposite calf.  Keep pressing your weight away from the floor with your palms, straighten through your arms and lift your eye gaze slightly towards your fingers.
handstand_eagle.Pose Benefits: Strengthens the arms, shoulders and back.  Improves focus and balance.  Strengthens the abdominal muscles.

handstand_splits.Pose Description: From an inverted position, balancing on the hands, one leg is extended forward and the other leg is extended back with equal and opposite force to maintain balance.  Depending on flexibility the legs are either extended straight or the knees are bent.  Arms are straight, the eye of the elbow is to the front of the room, Bandhas are engaged and the hands are pressed firmly down into the earth.  In this pose the arms are the fulcrum point that regulate the weight of the legs like a teeter-totter.  Keep the balance of the two legs equal in order to avoid toppling over.  The gaze is down and forward.
handstand_splits.Pose Benefits: Strengthens the shoulders, arms and wrists.  Stretches the belly.  Improves sense of balance.  Calms the brain and helps relieve stress and mild depression.

handstand_half_way.Pose Description: Begin in Handstand and maintain your core engagement.  Seal your legs to touch and lower your legs half way down.  Or, from Downward-Facing Dog, root down into your hands and shorten your stance slightly.  Bend your knees and float forward with straight legs into your pike handstand.  Keep your legs sealed and actively send energy to your toes.  Focus on stacking your wrists, shoulders, and hips in one line.  Eye gaze is slightly forward.
handstand_half_way.Pose Benefits: Improves balance and focus.  Strengthens the shoulders, arms and entire core.

handstand_tuck.Pose Description: Begin in Handstand and maintain your core engagement.  Bend your knees and lower them down towards your chest.  Or, from Downward-Facing Dog, root down into your hands and shorten your stance slightly.  Bend your knees and float forward, bringing your knees inward close to your chest.  Focus on stacking your wrists, shoulders, and hips in one line  .Eye gaze is slightly forward.
handstand_tuck.Pose Benefits: Improves balance and focus.  Strengthens the shoulders, arms and entire core.

forward_bend_preparation.Pose Description: Transitional pose to get into Standing Forward Bend.

handstand_lotus.Pose Description: From Handstand the ribs move back, the shoulders shift down and away from the ears, the pelvis tucks under for balance as the knees bend and the feet drop toward the head.  The heart center goes forward while the crown of the head lifts up.  The gaze is down or forward depending on balance and flexibility.
handstand_lotus.Pose Benefits: The entire front of the body is stretched, especially the chest, neck, spine and abs.  Strengthens the arms, shoulders and back.  Stimulates the abdominal organs and lungs.  Increases blood flow to the brain and circulation in the limbs.  Can increase fertility through stimulation of the reproductive organs.

handstand_scorpion.Pose Description: From Handstand the ribs move back, the shoulders shift down and away from the ears, the pelvis tucks under for balance as the knees bend and the feet drop toward the head.  The heart center goes forward while the crown of the head lifts up.  The gaze is down or forward depending on balance and flexibility.
handstand_scorpion.Pose Benefits: The entire front of the body is stretched, especially the chest, neck, spine and abs.  Strengthens the arms, shoulders and back.  Stimulates the abdominal organs and lungs.  Increases blood flow to the brain and circulation in the limbs.  Can increase fertility through stimulation of the reproductive organs.

handstand_scorpion_one_legged.Pose Description: Begin in Handstand.  Ground into your palms, keeping the arms straight and your shoulders over your wrists.  With your eye gaze slightly forward, drop the chest slightly and arch your back to shift your hips behind your shoulders.  Bend both knees and bring you toes towards the crown of your head coming into your Scorpion Handstand.  With control, lift one leg back into the sky and elongate and activate through to your toes.
handstand_scorpion_one_legged.Pose Benefits: Stretches the chest, neck, spine and abdominals.  Strengthens the arms, shoulders and back.  Improves balance and focus.

visvamitra.Pose Description: Begin in Lizard with Straight Arms and place your inside shoulder underneath your front thigh.  Curl up your back toes and pivot your foot down as if in a Warrior pose.  Ground the palm that is rooted under your front thigh and begin to shift your weight back slightly.  Bend your knee in more to lift your foot off the ground.  Use your opposite hand to catch the edge of your floating foot and begin to straighten your knee.  Ground down firmly to the outer edge of your back foot and your front palm.  Roll your chest through your arms up toward the sky and allow your gaze to follow.
visvamitra.Pose Benefits: Opens the side waist and torso.  Strengthens the upper body, wrists, and legs.  Stretches the outer hips and glutes.

lunge_shoulder_under_knee.Pose Description: Transitional pose to get into Flying Man, Flying Lizard or Super Soldier.

visvamitra_kneeling.Pose Description: Begin in Lizard with Straight Arms and drop down to your back knee.  Shorten your stance between your back knee and your front ankle.  Bring the top of your inside arm and elbow slightly under your front thigh then create a strong base with your arm by spreading your fingers wide.  Microbend your elbow to create a shelf for your front thigh to rest softly on.  Catch a hold of the outside edge of your foot with your free hand and begin to straighten your front leg and your supporting arm as much as possible.  Expand your chest through your extended leg and arm.  Take your gaze upward.
visvamitra_kneeling.Pose Benefits: Stretches and creates strength in the hip flexors, legs, arms and spine.

headstand_supported_revolved_split_legge.Pose Description: Come into your Supported Headstand.  Ensure you are on the very top of your head and you are pressing firmly into the ground with your forearms.  Widen your legs out to the sides and begin to initate a twist.  Keeping your legs wide, rotate your waist, hips, legs and toes towards one side.  Your torso, shoulders, arms and head stay static.  Keep the legs wide, come back to center and repeat the twist on the other side.
headstand_supported_revolved_split_legge.Pose Benefits: Increases circulation.  Strengthens the arms, legs and spine.

headstand_supported_one_legged_side.Pose Description: Begin in One Legged Supported Headstand.  Continue to engage your core and with control, walk your bottom foot out to the side bringing your foot in line with your head as much as possible.
headstand_supported_one_legged_side.Pose Benefits: Strengthens the arms, legs and spine.

headstand_supported_half_way.Pose Description: Begin by coming into your Supported Headstand.  Activate your legs and draw energy up toward your toes.  Find a focal point in front of you.  Keep your legs together and with your core engaged, begin to lower your legs down halfway until they are in an L-shape, and hold.
headstand_supported_half_way.Pose Benefits: Strengthens the arms, legs, and spine.  Tones the core and improved balance.

headstand_supported_bound_angle.Pose Name: Supported Headstand with Bound Angle Legs
headstand_supported_bound_angle.Pose Description: Come into your Supported Headstand.  Stay strong in your forearms and shoulders by pressing the earth away and engage your core.  Extend both legs out wide then bring the soles of your feet together while maintaining an external hip rotation.
headstand_supported_bound_angle.Pose Benefits: Strengthens the arms, legs, hips and spine.

headstand_supported_lotus.Pose Description: Come into your Supported Headstand.  Stay strong in your forearms and shoulders by pressing the earth away and engage your core.  Split your legs in the sky sending your left leg back to open the hip joint.  Bend your right knee and find an external rotation.  Reach your right foot as close to the left hip crease as possible then lift the right knee to the sky.  Do the same thing with the left leg while sending the right hip slightly back to make space for your left foot.  Reach your left foot as close to the right hip crease as possible.  Maintain the pose by continuing your external rotation of your hips.
headstand_supported_lotus.Pose Benefits: Strengthens the arms, legs, hips and spine.

headstand_supported_one_legged.Pose Description: Begin in Supported Headstand with Toes on the Ground.  Ensure you are on the very top of your head and you are pressing firmly into the ground with your forearms.  Walk your toes in towards your head and lift one leg up.  You can also enter this pose from Supported Headstand.  When entering from Supported Headstand, continue to engage your core and drop one leg down towards the ground until your toes find the earth.
headstand_supported_one_legged.Pose Benefits: Increases circulation.  Strengthens the arms, legs and spine.

headstand_supported_side.Pose Description: Come into your Supported Headstand.  Ensure you are on the very top of your head and you are pressing firmly into the ground with your forearms.  Initate a twist.  Rotate your waist, hips, legs and toes towards one side while keeping your torso, shoulders, arms and head static.  Repeat the twist on the other side.
headstand_supported_side.Pose Benefits: Increases circulation.  Strengthens the arms, legs and spine.

headstand_supported_eagle.Pose Description: From Supported Headstand, come into your Eagle legs.  Wrap one knee behind the other.  If you can, take the double wrap by hooking your toes behind your calf.  Keep pressing the weight away from the floor with your forearms so the crown of your head is softly resting.
headstand_supported_eagle.Pose Benefits: Strengthens the core, arms, legs and spine.  Sends blood flow and energy down to the brain.

headstand_supported_embryo.Pose Description: Begin in your Supported Headstand with Lotus Legs.  Stay strong in your forearms and shoulders by pressing the earth away and engage your core.  Lower your Lotus legs downward and bring your knees towards your chest and arms.  Stay and breathe maintaining your focal point.
headstand_supported_embryo.Pose Benefits: Strengthens the core, arms, legs, hips and spine.

headstand_supported_lotus_side.Pose Name: Side Supported Headstand with Lotus Legs
headstand_supported_lotus_side.Pose Description: Begin in Supported Headstand with Lotus Legs.  Maintaining your Lotus legs, rotate your hips to one side allowing your Lotus legs to rotate as well.  Repeat on the opposite side.
headstand_supported_lotus_side.Pose Benefits: Strengthens the arms, legs, hips and spine.

headstand_supported_tuck.Pose Description: Come into your Supported Headstand with Toes on the Ground.  Walk your feet closer to your head until your hips are stacked over your shoulders.  Engage your abdominals and keep pressing your forearms into the ground so there is little weight on the crown of your head.  Once stable, bring one knee in towards your chest and then the other.  Keep your knees together and squeeze them close in towards your body, heels close to your glutes.
headstand_supported_tuck.Pose Benefits: Strengthens the core, arms, legs and spine.

warrior_iii_eagle.Pose Description: From a standing position, place one elbow on top of the other for your eagle arm bind.  Lift your elbows in line with your shoulders and draw your forearms away from your face.  If possible, keep wrapping your arms until your palms meet; otherwise press the back of your hands towards each other.  Find a focal point in front of you and begin to shift your weight to one foot.  Root down into your standing leg and lift your opposite leg behind you.  Keep lifting it as you hinge your torso forward keeping your eagle arm bind.  Hips stay squared and the knee of your floating leg faces downward.  Flex your floating foot and engage your grounded leg.
warrior_iii_eagle.Pose Benefits: Stretches and strengthens the shoulders, arms and back muscles.  Strengthens the ankles and legs.  Tones the abdomen.  Improves balance and posture.

eagle_forward.Pose Description: Begin by coming into your deepest Eagle.  Keep a strong hook with your Eagle arms and Eagle legs.  Hinge forward with a rounded spine for your crunch.  Draw your navel in and engage your core.  Lift your elbows away from your body and face, making it your intention to place your interlaced elbows past your knees as your hips send back.
eagle_forward.Pose Benefits: Strengthens and stretches the ankles and calves.  Stretches the thighs, hips, shoulders, and upper back.  Strengthens the core.  Improves concentration.  Improves sense of balance.

warrior_i_forward.Pose Description: From a standing position, the legs are in a wide stance with the feet aligned and flat on the earth.  The back foot is in a 60-degree angle toward the front.  The hips are squared.  The inner thighs are rotated inward toward each other.  The front knee is bent in a 90-degree angle directly above the ankle.  The pelvis is tucked.  The ribcage is lifted.  The shoulder blades are back and down, squeezing together.  The hands can be together or separated and facing each other with the fingers spread wide.  The lower body stays static.  The upper torso gently bends forward from the crease of the hip with a straight line.  The gaze is forward.
warrior_i_forward.Pose Benefits: Stretches the chest, lungs, neck, belly and groin (psoas).  Strengthens the shoulders, arms and back muscles.  Strengthens and stretches the thighs, calves and ankles.

shoulderstand_unsupported.Pose Description: From Supported Shoulder Stand the arms lift straight up along the side body toward the sky with the fingers spread wide.  The gaze is up.
shoulderstand_unsupported.Pose Benefits: Calms the brain and helps relieve stress and mild depression.  Stimulates the thyroid and prostate glands and abdominal organs.  Stretches the shoulders and neck.  Tones the legs and buttocks.  Improves digestion.  Helps relieve the symptoms of menopause.  Reduces fatigue and alleviates insomnia.  Therapeutic for asthma.

warrior_twist_extended_bound.Pose Description: From Warrior II, bend the front knee and spin to the ball of the back foot as the torso lowers down onto the thigh, opening the heart center to the sky and lowering the bottom hand to the inside of the thigh with the palm planted firmly.  At the same time, reach the top arm and hand up and overhead extending in a straight line toward the front.  To take the bind then wrap the top arm around and under the backside of the torso and grasp the bottom hand at the wrist if possible.  Minimize lateral flexion of the spine while rotating the torso open.  Press the elbow and the shoulder against the bent knee in an isometric contraction to keep the knee aligned and leverage the rotation of the torso.  The gaze is to upper fingertips and the neck is relaxed.  As all twists lengthen and soften the belly, extend the spine with each inhalation, and increase the twist as you exhale.
warrior_twist_extended_bound.Pose Benefits: Strengthens and stretches the legs, the knees, and the ankles.  Stretches the groins, the spine, the chest, the lungs, and the shoulders.  Stimulates abdominal organs.  Increases stamina.  Improves digestion and aids elimination.  Improves balance.

lunge_bind.Pose Description: From Extended Side Angle, one arm is wrapped underneath the front thigh while the other hand wraps around the torso behind the back in a bind.  The ribcage is lifted and the pelvis tucked.  The heart is open.  The gaze is toward the sky.
lunge_bind.Pose Benefits: Creates flexible strength.  Promotes stability in the front and back of the torso.  Tones the lower body.  Opens the shoulders.

side_angle_extended.Pose Description: From a standing position, the legs are in a wide stance with the feet aligned and flat on the earth.  The inner thighs scissor toward each other with Mula Bandha engaged.  The front knee is bent in a 90-degree angle and tracks the front ankle.  The back leg is straight with most of the body's weight pressed into the outside edge of the back foot gripping the earth.  One arm is actively reaching forward while the opposite palm is rooted either on the inside or the outside of the bent front knee, depending on the degree of flexibility available.  Beginning students should keep their head in a neutral position, looking straight forward, or turn it to look down and protect the neck.  More experienced students can turn the head and gaze up at the top hand.
side_angle_extended.Pose Benefits: Wrings out the lower back and the digestive and vital organs of the mid-body.  Opens the chest.  Stretches the pectoralis minor muscles.

wheel_leg_up.Pose Description: From Wheel, extend one leg straight up to the sky with active toes.  The gaze is forward.
wheel_leg_up.Pose Benefits: Strengthens the arms, wrists, legs, buttocks, abs, and spine.  Stimulates the thyroid and pituitary.  Increases energy and counteracts depression.  Therapeutic for asthma, back pain, infertility, and osteoporosis.

wheel_preparation.Pose Description: Transitional pose to get into Wheel or Half Wheel.From Corpse, bend both knees and walk your feet in toward your glutes.  Bend your elbows and place your palms by your ears.  Your knees and feet should be hip width apart with the toes facing forward.  Your palms should be flat with the fingers facing forward.  Your head is on the ground and your eye gaze is upward.

wheel_head_down.Pose Description: Begin in Wheel (Preparation).  Lift your hips and press into your hands until you can drop to the crown of your head.  Gaze is at the back.  Keep hugging your legs and arms into your midline.
wheel_head_down.Pose Benefits: Strengthens the arms, wrists, legs, buttocks, abs, and spine.

downward_dog_leg_up_stack_hips.Pose Name: Three Legged Downward-Facing Dog with Hip Opener
downward_dog_leg_up_stack_hips.Pose Description: From Downward-Facing Dog, one leg reaches up toward the sky, the top knee is bent and the hips are stacked.  The shoulders are squared to the earth.  Heart is open.  The shoulder blades squeeze together and the forehead drops down toward the earth.  The gaze is to the back.
downward_dog_leg_up_stack_hips.Pose Benefits: Tones and strengthens the standing leg.  Improves flexibility.  Opens the hips.

horizon_lunge.Pose Description: Begin in a Lunge with Arm Extended Up.  Reach your top arm up higher into the sky then, at the same time, extend it toward the back as you roll onto the edges of your feet.  Flex both feet to protect your joints.
